Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I don’t know what the policewoman wants.

She says call her Michelle, even though she’s a grownup and Mummy said it’s rude not to call policemen or policewomen officer.

Where is my Mummy? I want to know where Mummy is.

I want to know where Daddy is too. I kept asking Michelle, but she just kept asking me all her questions, and they were all the same. She keeps wanting to know what the man who kicked down our door and walked into our house looked like. And if he had a gun with him. Or a knife.

I don’t think Michelle is very clever, even if she’s a grownup.

She’s outside now talking with the big policeman, and she still didn’t tell me when Mummy and Daddy will come back. She said soon but she’s a liar. It’s not fair. I already answered all her questions.

She’s mean.

I can hear Michelle talking to the big policeman outside. She calls him Dave, she doesn’t say officer. Dave is even older than Michelle, he must be a hundred years old or even maybe a thousand hundred.

What’s she saying?

I don’t understand. She keeps on using big words to sound clever.

Maybe when Daddy comes back I’ll ask him what “suspected homicide” means.

Now Dave’s talking. He’s nearly whispering to Michelle. I think he doesn’t want me to hear what he’s saying. Mummy sometimes does that when she’s on the phone with someone.

Dave says they found the murder weapon on the floor.

Maybe him and Michelle are playing one of those games my big brother Oliver likes playing?

I miss Oliver. He goes to a school in America that teaches grownups how to be doctors. Michelle asked me about him, and she said she’ll phone Oliver to come pick me up. She lied because she still hasn’t phoned him yet and it’s been ages.

Michelle is saying something now. She keeps on talking about the father and the mother. That means Daddy and Mummy, I think.

She said the father was found unconcsious on the couch and he’s in the hospital now.

Michelle’s a liar. She said Daddy would be here soon. What’s unconcious?

Maybe they mean Daddy was pretending to be dead. Sometimes Daddy lies on the couch and sticks out his tongue, and I tickle him until he sneezes and I win. Maybe grownups don’t know how to play dead like Daddy. I should tell Michelle.

Dave is talking now. He’s telling Michelle to be quieter.

I’m going to listen even harder.

Dave says they found the mother upstairs in the same condition as the father.

I don’t understand at all. Now they’re talking about suspects. Daddy said one time that those are people the police think did something wrong.

Michelle is saying Alan Thompson. I know who he is! Daddy likes talking about him with Mummy all the time whenever they talk about when Daddy fired Alan from his shop. Only “fire” is not like proper fire and Daddy sometimes calls him that bastard. Mummy sometimes forgets to tell him to speak quieter.

Dave just said my name. Maybe Michelle is going to come in again and ask me more dumb questions.

No, she didn’t. She’s still outside. She says they have good reason to suspect Thompson. What’s that mean? She says the description matches what they’ve got. She says without a doubt it was him because our guys caught him when he was running away.

Now Dave is calling him that bastard too. He sounds angry. Michelle just sounds upset.

Why aren’t they talking about Oliver? I want my big brother. Where is he?

Michelle is talking about that poor girl. She just blew her nose. Dave is saying something about getting more tissues.

He’s gone. I can hear his feet, he’s really loud.

Maybe when he comes with the tissues Michelle will come back and tell me where Mummy and Daddy are.

Dave is taking ages.

I’m hungry and I’m sleepy. Michelle is still blowing her nose. I don’t know where Dave is. I can’t hear anyone else.

I think they forgot about me.

I want to go home. Why can’t they just take me home?

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
It’s summer! I love the woods behind my house. Those big big trees in the backyard have big big purple berries on them now! Squish they make my fingers pretty!

Mommy likes pretty things, so I run into the kitchen and show her my pretty purple fingers.

Now I am sitting outside on the back porch, wet from my outside shower. I guess Mommy doesn’t think purple is pretty.

My sisters are inside, I can see them coloring through the window. Now Mommy looks happy. She looks at my sister’s drawing of a yellow flower. She’s smiling. I see her say,“Oh pretty!”

My hands are cold from the shower but my face is hot. My eyes feel hot and sore and big. I cover them with my cold fingers. That’s a little better.

I peep through my fingers. There is no house right next to ours. Just tall tall itchy scratchy grass and flowers all over. I like to catch butterflies there sometimes. Maybe there is a butterfly now?

Ah! AH! No, no butterflies, but I see the flowers! Yellow flowers. Mommy thinks yellow flowers are pretty! I should get some for Mommy, then she will smile at me like sister. I can pick so many so many for her! Then she will be happy.

Mommy… Mommy doesn’t like flowers. She only likes picture flowers. Flower flowers get yellow on the white carpet. She yells, the yellow makes her sneeze! I didn’t know yellow can make you sneeze. I’m outside again. I’m wet again.

There’s only one flower left in my hand. Mommy dumped too much water on them. They look like little pieces of yellow paper on the porch.

My sisters are playing dolls on the carpet now. I think they had a hotdog for lunch. Mommy is in the kitchen washing their dishes. She doesn’t look happy.

Daddy walks in from the garage, he’s home! I can come in soon probably. I watch him kiss Mommy’s cheek. My sisters run over and hug him, “How are my pretty girls?” Daddy kisses Mommy again. She smiles and kisses him too. Everyone smiles.

Kisses, Mommy likes kisses!

I can come in a little later, when I’m dry. I get to eat some goldfish and apples. Daddy lets us watch some cartoons before bed. I get a room all to myself because I’m the biggest. My sisters share.

Mommy is in her big bed. Some old man is shouting on the TV. He sounds angry. Maybe he needs a kiss too. Mommy is watching the man, she doesn’t see me come in. Surprise kiss!

MUAH! I give my best kiss on her cheek.

Mommy makes a long big noise, like her tummy hurts, and wipes all of my kiss away with a tissue. She goes into the bathroom and brushes her teeth. Spit spit spit.

She asks why I’m still standing there. It’s bed time. GO. TO. BED.

I guess Mommy only likes Daddy kisses.

Daddy always reads us a story before we sleep. Tonight God is in a garden, with two brothers. They both give God a gift but he only likes one. God doesn’t like what the older brother gives him. So God loves the little brother more. The big brother is the bad brother so he has to go away. Forever.

Daddy finishes the story so I walk to my room. He kisses my sisters goodnight. I can still hear the angry man Mommy is watching on TV. Then he kisses me goodnight. My heart wants to tell Daddy Mommy doesn’t like my gifts either. That Mommy never smiles at me like at my sisters. That Mommy loves them more, like God loves the little brother more in the story. That mommy wants me to go away.

My heart feels too close to my mouth, like a big rock. I can’t tell him again. Again.

I’m like the bad brother in the story,

I won’t tell him.

Daddy leaves the door open a little, so I don’t see the monsters in the window. I can see my sisters’ room across the hall. Their door is open too. But the TV man stops yelling.

Mommy! I can see her, in the hallway! She is kissing us goodnight too! My heart is big and close to my mouth again but now like a big balloon! When she comes in I will say sorry for my purple fingers. Sorry for the yellow sneezing. Sorry. Tomorrow I will be better and make her happy at me. I’ll tell her I pinky promise. I’m so happy I get to say goodnight.

She’s going into my sisters’ room but that’s okay. That’s ok, they can get their kiss first. They whisper and giggle for a few minutes. Oh good oh good. She is happy. I get to say goodnight. My big happy heart balloon gets bigger. It will all be ok. I snuggle into my pillow, waiting for Mommy.

Waiting

waiting…

Mommy?

I hear the angry man in the TV shouting again.

Mommy doesn’t like me.

I… I don’t want to go away.

I can come in a little later, when I’m dry. I get to eat some goldfish and apples. Daddy lets us watch some cartoons before bed. I get a room all to myself because I’m the biggest. My sisters share.

Mommy is in her big bed. Some old man is shouting on the TV. He sounds angry. Maybe he needs a kiss too. Mommy is watching the man, she doesn’t see me come in. Surprise kiss!

MUAH! I give my best kiss on her cheek.

Mommy makes a long big noise, like her tummy hurts, and wipes all of my kiss away with a tissue. She goes into the bathroom and brushes her teeth. Spit spit spit.

She asks why I’m still standing there. It’s bed time. GO. TO. BED.

I guess Mommy only likes Daddy kisses.

Daddy always reads us a story before we sleep. Tonight God is in a garden, with two brothers. They both give God a gift but he only likes one. God doesn’t like what the older brother gives him. So God loves the little brother more. The big brother is the bad brother so he has to go away. Forever.

Daddy finishes the story so I walk to my room. He kisses my sisters goodnight. I can still hear the angry man Mommy is watching on TV. Then he kisses me goodnight. My heart wants to tell Daddy Mommy doesn’t like my gifts either. That Mommy never smiles at me like at my sisters. That Mommy loves them more, like God loves the little brother more in the story. That mommy wants me to go away.

My heart feels too close to my mouth, like a big rock. I can’t tell him again. Again.

I’m like the bad brother in the story,

I won’t tell him.

Daddy leaves the door open a little, so I don’t see the monsters in the window. I can see my sisters’ room across the hall. Their door is open too. But the TV man stops yelling.

Mommy! I can see her, in the hallway! She is kissing us goodnight too! My heart is big and close to my mouth again but now like a big balloon! When she comes in I will say sorry for my purple fingers. Sorry for the yellow sneezing. Sorry. Tomorrow I will be better and make her happy at me. I’ll tell her I pinky promise. I’m so happy I get to say goodnight.

She’s going into my sisters’ room but that’s okay. That’s ok, they can get their kiss first. They whisper and giggle for a few minutes. Oh good oh good. She is happy. I get to say goodnight. My big happy heart balloon gets bigger. It will all be ok. I snuggle into my pillow, waiting for Mommy.

Waiting

waiting…

Mommy?

I hear the angry man in the TV shouting again.

Mommy doesn’t like me.

I… I don’t want to go away.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
My daddy has got good hands.

Every day when I go to school, he helps me to tie my shoes.

When my toy car breaked, he fixed it back for me.

When a big scary man tried to take me away, daddy beat up the big scary man and saved me.

When I fell down, it hurt so much. My daddy picked me up and hugged me, and said it's okay, my dear, daddy has you.

Yes, my daddy is the best. He has good hands that can help me.

Then one day daddy walked into my room, and said I love you, then he left the room.

He was wearing weird clothes.

It had funny puddles that were dark and not arranged nicely.

After that day, daddy didn't come home for the next week.

He also didn't come home next week.

He also didn't come home next next week also.

He also didn't come home next next next week also.

I keep asking mommy where is daddy. She keeps telling me he has gone to fight bad people. I asked mommy if they were like the big scary man who daddy beat up. She said yes.

Then another day when I was walking home from school, when I reached the door, I heard mommy crying.

I runned in and asked mommy what's wrong?

Then I saw it, daddy had come home.

But wait, there is something wrong.

Where are daddy's arms?

Also, where are his hands?

I looked up, and daddy was crying as well.

He said: "I'm sorry, my dear, I can't help you anymore."

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
My best friend Damien won't talk to me anymore. I don't understand why. He told me that his parents say I'm dirty. That my parents are dirty. That my family should be ashamed. He says that he doesn't want to be around icky people. I asked grandma if I stunk, but she said no.

The next day at recess my friends were playing house. I wanted to play house, but Damien was there and he told me I couldn't play. I told Damien I had taken a bath, but he said it didn't matter. I played with Legos alone. It was fun, I made a monster, but Damien came over and stomped on it. I told on Damien, and Ms.S made him say he was sorry. I don't think he was actually sorry.

For class we had to draw pictures of our families. I was excited. Grandma says I'm a very good drawer and frames all my pictures. I drew my dog Peanut and my kitty Oreo. Then I drew me next to my dads. Damien came over and told me that's why he hates me. It took me awhile to figure out, but I got it. Damien must not like animals.

Questions: What are some of the most badass poems ever?
Answers:
Definitely badass from one of my favourite poets, Maya Angelou:

Phenomenal Woman
By Maya Angelou


Source:
153. MAYA ANGELOU: Phenomenal Woman


Pretty women wonder where my secret lies.
I'm not cute or built to suit a fashion model's size
But when I start to tell them,
They think I'm telling lies.
I say,
It's in the reach of my arms
The span of my hips,
The stride of my step,
The curl of my lips.
I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

I walk into a room
Just as cool as you please,
And to a man,
The fellows stand or
Fall down on their knees.
Then they swarm around me,
A hive of honey bees.
I say,
It's the fire in my eyes,
And the flash of my teeth,
The swing in my waist,
And the joy in my feet.
I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

Men themselves have wondered
What they see in me.
They try so much
But they can't touch
My inner mystery.
When I try to show them
They say they still can't see.
I say,
It's in the arch of my back,
The sun of my smile,
The ride of my breasts,
The grace of my style.
I'm a woman

Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

Now you understand
Just why my head's not bowed.
I don't shout or jump about
Or have to talk real loud.
When you see me passing
It ought to make you proud.
I say,
It's in the click of my heels,
The bend of my hair,
the palm of my hand,
The need of my care,
'Cause I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.


I had already answered it here:
Sayoni Mitra's answer to Which is your favourite poem and why?

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
“Sometimes my mom brings guys over at night. She says they are my uncle, but they're never at the family cookout.”

“My dad and babysitter like to play hide and seek with me, but they are always in the same hiding spot. I don't think they know how to play the game right.”

“My mom always cries when she opens the mail. I don't know who bill is, but he needs to stop sending mean letters to my mom.”

“One day my mom came home with my baby brother. The next day my dad said he was going to the grocery store, but he hasn't gotten back yet. I think he got lost on the way home. Sometimes mommy says she gets lost on the way home and it takes hours to get home.”

“My mom loves tic tacs. She never even shares.”

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
*Trigger Warning: mentions of mental illness and suicide*

Daddy always used to take me to the swings whenever we went to play in the park.

After he came home from work, he’d take me by the hand and we’d run to the park. And when I got on the swings, he’d push my back as I swung higher and higher, until the sky looked so close it felt as if I was flying.

When I was over, he’d pat my head with shining eyes, saying “Did you have fun, Emma?” And then, I would always nod and tell him how wonderful it was to feel like I can touch the blue sky.

I loved my daddy, very much.

A few months ago, daddy stopped taking me to the park to play and stayed alone in his room after he came home instead. I missed going to the park with daddy.

I asked mommy why he wouldn’t come out from his room, and she told me that it was because he was really sad.

I wondered if he was playing with his toys in his room, just like how I play with my dolls when I’m sad. So I decided to share my dolls with him so he can be happy again.

When I knocked on daddy’s room, no one answered. I called for daddy many times, but he didn’t say anything.

I gave up on waiting and twisted the doorknob. The room was really quiet and a whole lot messier than when I last saw it. I saw daddy asleep on his bed, so I poked his warm body a couple of times until he woke up.

“Sorry I didn’t realize you wanted to get in the room, my little Emma,” he said quietly. “What’s wrong?”

“I heard from mommy that you’re really sad right now. So I brought you my dolls so you can be happy again!” I proudly showed him the dolls I brought for him— my three favorites, Molly, Daisy and Alex.

“Thank you for the dolls, Emma. I love you,” daddy told me, his eyes shining ever so slightly.

“I love you too, daddy!” I exclaimed, giving him a kiss on his cheek. “And when you’re happy again, will you take me to the park so we can go on the swings?”

“Of course I will, my darling. I’ll take you to the park so we can play on the swings,” daddy promised me.

I loved my daddy, very much.

My daddy still won’t come out from his room. Now, he won’t even go to work and just stays locked up in his room all day.

I asked mommy if daddy was still sad, and she told me he was. I even asked mommy if she would take me to the park instead, but she said no because she had to take care of daddy.

I really missed my daddy. I wanted to see him happy again. So, I decided to bring him even more of my favorite dolls so he can play with them all the time.

I knocked on daddy’s door, but again, there was no answer. Unlike last time, I didn’t call for daddy but just opened the door instead.

The first thing I saw were daddy’s feet. Behind him were my dolls, Molly, Daisy and Alex, lined up perfectly on his bed. When I looked up, I saw that his eyes weren’t shining anymore — it stared blankly towards the wall instead. His neck had gotten really long, and it looked like he had made his own personal swing inside his room.

I wished he took me to the park and let me go play on the swings instead of him playing by himself.

Mommy came behind me and I heard her gasp, the way she always does when something’s wrong.

“Daddy went to play on the swings without me,” I pouted, hugging the dolls I had brought for him tightly.

With her phone in one hand and tears in her eyes, mommy replied, “Emma darling, he went to the park in heaven. Let’s go downstairs and wait until the police officers come, okay?”

I miss my daddy.

But I’ll always love him, very much.

I wondered if he was playing with his toys in his room, just like how I play with my dolls when I’m sad. So I decided to share my dolls with him so he can be happy again.

When I knocked on daddy’s room, no one answered. I called for daddy many times, but he didn’t say anything.

I gave up on waiting and twisted the doorknob. The room was really quiet and a whole lot messier than when I last saw it. I saw daddy asleep on his bed, so I poked his warm body a couple of times until he woke up.

“Sorry I didn’t realize you wanted to get in the room, my little Emma,” he said quietly. “What’s wrong?”

“I heard from mommy that you’re really sad right now. So I brought you my dolls so you can be happy again!” I proudly showed him the dolls I brought for him— my three favorites, Molly, Daisy and Alex.

“Thank you for the dolls, Emma. I love you,” daddy told me, his eyes shining ever so slightly.

“I love you too, daddy!” I exclaimed, giving him a kiss on his cheek. “And when you’re happy again, will you take me to the park so we can go on the swings?”

“Of course I will, my darling. I’ll take you to the park so we can play on the swings,” daddy promised me.

I loved my daddy, very much.

My daddy still won’t come out from his room. Now, he won’t even go to work and just stays locked up in his room all day.

I asked mommy if daddy was still sad, and she told me he was. I even asked mommy if she would take me to the park instead, but she said no because she had to take care of daddy.

I really missed my daddy. I wanted to see him happy again. So, I decided to bring him even more of my favorite dolls so he can play with them all the time.

I knocked on daddy’s door, but again, there was no answer. Unlike last time, I didn’t call for daddy but just opened the door instead.

The first thing I saw were daddy’s feet. Behind him were my dolls, Molly, Daisy and Alex, lined up perfectly on his bed. When I looked up, I saw that his eyes weren’t shining anymore — it stared blankly towards the wall instead. His neck had gotten really long, and it looked like he had made his own personal swing inside his room.

I wished he took me to the park and let me go play on the swings instead of him playing by himself.

Mommy came behind me and I heard her gasp, the way she always does when something’s wrong.

“Daddy went to play on the swings without me,” I pouted, hugging the dolls I had brought for him tightly.

With her phone in one hand and tears in her eyes, mommy replied, “Emma darling, he went to the park in heaven. Let’s go downstairs and wait until the police officers come, okay?”

I miss my daddy.

But I’ll always love him, very much.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I hate momma.

She lays in bed all day, she doesn’t have time for me anymore. She doesn’t cook, clean, talk, play or anything!

Yesterday, I was playing with my toys & momma told me that I’d have to make my own lunch!

I hate her.

Momma used to be so pretty.

She used to have hair like goldilocks, or rapunzel. Her eyes were blue.

Momma’s not pretty anymore.

I went into her room yesterday, all her hair was gone, she was coughing up blood & her eyes were dark.

It’s like a monster ate up momma.

I knew it would happen one day.

Daddy & momma are going to the ‘hozpeetal’ tomorrow. But, not in an ambulance.

Daddy says momma is staying overnight, like a sleepover! Why is momma staying overnight? I want to stay overnight. It looks so fun!

Momma didn’t come home.

I asked daddy,

He just cried. I asked about the monster that killed Momma, Daddy says the monsters name is Cancer.

I hate cancer.

Cancer isn’t pretty.

Cancer isn’t nice.

Cancer doesn’t talk or play with you.

Cancer is bad.

Cancer took Momma.

Questions: What are the most inspiring poems ever written?
Answers:
'Ekla Chalo Re' by Rabindranath Tagore

<Translation of the Original Bengali Poem>

If they answer not to thy call walk alone
If they are afraid and cower mutely facing the wall,
O thou unlucky one,
open thy mind and speak out alone.

If they turn away, and desert you when crossing the wilderness,
O thou unlucky one,
trample the thorns under thy tread,
and along the blood-lined track travel alone.

If they do not hold up the light when the night is troubled with storm,
O thou unlucky one,
with the thunder flame of pain ignite thy own heart,
and let it burn alone.

Questions: Can you write a short poem in 4 lines?
Answers:
She bears the pain , She can handle grief

She's a women , whom you can't beat

She’ll take her stand , she'll not ignore

She will run for miles even if you abhor

She's a woman whom you can't stop

You'll see her name , in the top

PS : For all women out there

Sakshi

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
Daddy picked me up from school today. Mrs. Schmidt looks confused and said she thought it was Mommy’s turn to drive me home, but Daddy promised it was his.

He let me sit in the front seat, Mommy never does that. He even said we would get to have ice cream soon!

Daddy doesn’t like listening to music. In his car we always listen to the news, even though he knows I think it’s boring.

I try to tell him how boring it is again, but he tells me to be quiet, he’s waiting to hear something.

I wonder what he wants to hear.

I’m tired of waiting. I just want to go home. I think we passed our house, but it doesn’t matter because we’re having ice cream soon.

Daddy looks worried still, I don’t know what he needs to listen for.

He gives me his phone to play on, but he makes me promise not to text Mommy because she is busy.

I didn’t want to text her anyways. Games are more fun.

When it starts to get dark, the screen lights up the car a little and the walls glow.

My favorite game to play is Candy Crush but sometimes I like pretending to write emails like Daddy does.

I am trying to write a pretend one to Mrs. Schmidt when Daddy’s phone starts shaking.

There’s words at the top of the screen.

I try to sound them out like we practiced in class.

Ah-mm-ber A-leer-t, I say in my head.

I don’t know what it means so I hand the phone back to Daddy. I’m tired anyways.

He looks worried again. I wish I hadn’t given it back.

He starts driving faster and he tells me we’re going to play a game.

“Just like hide-and-seek, you can go a little under your seat.”

Hide-and-seek is my favorite game, Daddy and Mommy and me used to play it all the time.

I can’t see very much under the seat. It’s dark but there is also sometimes little bits of red light. It’s like it’s flashing.

Daddy keeps going faster.

I don’t want to play this game anymore.

The lights got brighter and I can hear another car going fast just like us.

Finally, Daddy stops the car. I go forward a little, but it’s OK because it doesn’t hurt.

Daddy tells me to get back in my seat.

I can see lots of police near the window now. I wonder what is happening.

Daddy looks at me, he still seems worried.

“I love you,” he says and steps out of the car.

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
Hi Diary,

today we had to go to the hospital, Because I have an ouchie lump on my neck And it keeps growing. It hurts lots and makes me cry. When we were there the doctor was nice, the doctor told me my lump was naughty for hurting me.

daddy then took me outside and we played with the little house in the room with the lots of chairs. Mummy stayed and talked to the doctor. I think the doctor was mean to mummy, as she made mummy cry. I don’t like it when mummy cries it makes me want to cry. Mummy gave me a hug and said she loves me.

Bye diary

hi diary,

we Went to the hospital again, we didn’t see the mean doctor today. We got to see a nice lady instead. She played with me and we put a dolly in a big white donut. She said that the donut is loud. but I get to watch movies when I go in. She showed me lots of movies and I chose a mermaid one. There was a mean man, he put a needle into me and it hurted. He put some big plastic ear muffs on me but they weren’t fluffy like mummy’s . He made me lie in a big donut like the nice lady had shown me, but it was loud and hurt my ears. I don’t like it.

i had to lie on a tray and it hurted my back. I cried lots as i didn’t like atall. Mummy then told me to stay still and I get ice cream. I tried my best.

mummy got be ice cream after I got out the loud donut. She got me mint ice cream and it had chocolate in it, it was very yummy.

mummys phone rang and she cried again. Why is mummy always crying

Bye diary

hi diary,

mummy had to take me to new hospital today. She said I was going to go in a quiet donut. But I need to lie very still. These aren’t donuts, donuts should be yummy not hurty.

another mean doctor came in, they said I was going in a pet scan. I like pets pets are nice. They put me in a room for ever. And put more needles into me. The mean doctor said that it’s fairy magic. I like fairy’s. I’m hungry as mummy won’t feed me. Does mummy not love me no more?

this Donut isn’t loud like the other donut, I like this donut more. Now I can eat some food. I had some cookies. They were very yummy. We had to sit in a room for ages. I then needed another time in the donut. This isn’t fun.

after I left that donut, I could go home.

we had sausage and mash for dinner my favourite.

night diary.

diary

im scared, why do mummy and daddy make me go to hospital all time. I haven’t hurt my leg again.

mummy says I’m going to have a magic sleeping juice. She says doctors aren’t mean. She says they want to help me. But they hurted me that don’t help.

mummy says they want to see if my lump is a bad one or not.

im having magic sleeping juice now. I can’t drink it. They put it in a plaster on my hand.

bye diary.

hi diary,

i am awake from my magic sleeping juice. My neck hurts lots. And I’m not to move it. Mummy has to feed me. I’m not a baby I’m six. Ivan feed myself. Silly mummy. The foods yucky. I want to go home.

bye diary

hi diary

mummy cried today. She sed I have canser. Gran gran had that. But now gran gran is in heaven. I want to see gran gran. Daddy keeps kiss my head and hugging me. Mummy keeps crying. Am I going to heaven like gran gran.

I need more magic sleeping juice, as the doctors need to put a door in me for a thing called keemo.

night diary

I start keemo today diary, I hope she’s nice.

diary

keemo is mean. She’s made my hair go away. Now I have no hair like grandad I’m not that old. Silly keemo. Mummy got me a pink wig! I like pink!

keemo makes me sick, a mean doctor put a worm up my nose and puts milk down it. silly doctor. Milks for me not for worms.

bye diary

hey diary

its my 8th birthday today. And my final round of chemo. I hope to be able to go to school more now. I’ve had lots of doctors now. And some doctors have made me sleepy to help my neck. I hope I don’t need chemo again.

i might get to be a nurse when I’m older. The nurses who look after me are all very kind.

bye diary

dear diary

I guess I haven’t updated for a long time. I’m now 11 and am starting secondary school in September. I got the all clear after my last entry. I have relapsed though, but I hope to get better again. The cancer has spread to my lung my brain and my spine. The doctors are now unsure what they can do for me. I am going to have more chemo to see if they can help me again. I hope so, I do much want to attend secondary school with Anna and Millie.
good night diary.

diary

I've made it it’s my 12th birthday. The doctor said my cancer is terminal quite a while ago. Sorry I didn’t update. I’m going into year 8 soon an I’m so excited. It’s half term in 3 weeks and we’re going to Disney land. I still can’t believe I’m 12, we didn’t think I’d make it. I feel very ill on my chemo but have had a slice of birthday cake, which I hope to keep down. I’m going to go celebrate with my family now. I’ll update soon.

dear diary, 16 days till Disney

dear diary 15 days till Disney

dear diary 14 days till Disney

dear diary 13 days till Disney

dear diary 12 days till Disney

dear diary 11 days till Disney

dear diary 10 days till Disney

dear diary 9 days till Disney

dear diary 8 days till Disney

dear diary 7 days till Disney

dear diary 6 days

5 days

4 days

3 days

2 days

Tomorrow!!

dear diary, OMG it’s today. I’m going to Disney and I can not wait. I have never been so excited before. It’s odd to think it’s my dying wish, but yay Disney. I hope I stay well as I’ve been stable the last 2 weeks.

dear diary

omg Disney is amazing, I’m exhausted but it is great. I’ve been on the Peter Pan ride and I’ve flown on dumbo. I know childish. BUT WHO CARES!!! Yolo. This is my wish and I will make the most of it.

dear diary,

I can’t breath. I passed out on a ride. They had to stop it to get me off. They put me in an ambulance and I’m currently in the hospital.

im coughing up blood and my lungs are getting tighter. I think I’m going to die soon. I want to be a nurse, I want to go to school. I want to dance at prom. I really want to dance at prom more than anything. Mum and dad are sobbing uncontrollably. Holding and kissing my hands.

everything's gone dark as the heart monitor beeps. My mum howls. As my dad falls over his feet running for the nurse. I stand at the end of the bed, I look at my body lying there. My mum whispering to me that I’ll pull through. The cardiac arrest buzzer gets pulled as everyone runs in to try and bring me back. Mum asked for some time alone. She pulled me into her arms squeezing my body tight and sobbing. I slowly walk towards her. Kiss her forehead. Dad walk in putting his hand on her shoulder. I stand and I hold both their hands. Tears stream down both their cheeks, as they stare at my body one moment longer. The doctors walk in and Wheel the bed to the door. I look at the bed, then at my parents. I whisper “ I love you mummy, I love you daddy. I’m so sorry”

they fall to the floor as I follow my body out. I’ll never be a nurse, I’ll never go to prom, I’ll never get to go to school again. I smile as I see the corridor of light. I hope Gran gran is up there. I hope my parents will be okay.
good bye diary

im at peace x

Questions: What are the most inspiring poems ever written?
Answers:
A Dream Within A Dream

Take this kiss upon the brow!
And, in parting from you now,
Thus much let me avow--
You are not wrong, who deem
That my days have been a dream;
Yet if hope has flown away
In a night, or in a day,
In a vision, or in none,
Is it therefore the less gone?
All that we see or seem
Is but a dream within a dream.

I stand amid the roar
Of a surf-tormented shore,
And I hold within my hand
Grains of the golden sand--
How few! yet how they creep
Through my fingers to the deep,
While I weep--while I weep!
O God! can I not grasp
Them with a tighter clasp?
O God! can I not save
One from the pitiless wave?
Is all that we see or seem
But a dream within a dream?

Questions: How can
Answers:
I had answered a similar question on "How do I write?"
Here goes the same and pretty lame answer.

I wait for the clock to strike 12, I wait for the night,
That is when I start to write.
I pick up the diary gifted by my friend and a pen,
Start scribbling sitting in my den.
I want no disturbance, I close my door,
Think of people who I am writing for.
I like it when the story is emotional, when there is a twist,
Look at my window covered in mist.
There are days, when a real life incident takes up a form,
I get excited, hoping the story would cause a storm.
There are days when I fail to think, though I try hard,
Not able to write anything, I feel sad.
I follow the principle of KISS: keep it simple, stupid,
When nothing strikes my mind, I think of Cupid.

I tried to write a poem, make things rhyme,
Forgive me for the above shit, it's daytime and hence, not in my prime.

Questions: If you are on a high caliber poetry site and 100 people read your poem but no one comments does that indicate your poem sucks?
Answers:
Not at all.

The Internet is divided into three main groups when it comes to content:

Passive viewers- these are people who will read, watch, or listen to, but nothing more. They won't like, share, upvote, rate, thumbs up, or comment. If the site doesn't have a view counter, you won't even know they were there. These account for around 95-99%

Active viewers- these are people that view and submit their opinion in the form of likes, ratings, etc. They don't want to offer criticism in any real sense, but are happy to click some button to say what they enjoyed. If no such button exists, they become indistinguishable from the passive viewers.

Interactors- these are the people who will comment. They will write their opinion and their views. These account for around 0.05% of people who actually saw what you produced.

Don't believe me, compare the number of views to the number of upvotes on Quora answers. It's usually 1–2 upvotes per hundred views, if that. Now compare the comments to the upvotes. It's usually 1–5 comments for every hundred upvotes.

It's not that your content sucks. It's that you'll need around 1000 views before anyone even thinks of commenting.

Questions: What are some interesting poems you have written during hard times of your life?
Answers:
*LIE



Lie,
A beautiful thing that can bring a smile.

Lie,
A word that can brighten up my eyes.

Lie,
‘Coz it reminds me of love and bliss.

Lie,
‘Coz I am used to it.

Lie,
‘Coz that’s the only truth.


Those late nights early morning talk,

At 3A.M. when it was time for ghost souls to take a walk.

When you used to tell me a sweet lie,

That you will not give up on me, will stay by my side.

And I used to believe them all that you say,

And stick that smile on my lips for whole next day.

Take me again to place I used to be,

Where I used to believe that you and me,

Will remain forever, even though it was a lie,

It has that power to keep my soul alive.

This truth is hurting me, killing inside.

And it feels like am stabbed with a sharp edged knife.

Lie to me,
‘Coz I believe each love words said by thee.

Lie,
‘Coz it has beautiful rhyme in it.

Lie,
‘Coz it has all the promises, even though fake,

Lie,
‘Coz I am used to it.

Lie,
‘Coz that’s the only truth.

Edit: Thank you everyone for my first 100+ upvotes :)

Questions: Are there poems to send to a friend whose dog died?
Answers:
Absolutely, there are poems that can help console a friend grieving the loss of their furry family member. The loss of a pet is no trivial matter—they’re part of the family, and for some, this might be their closest companion we’re talking about.

Do Not Stand At My Grave and Weep by Mary Elizabeth Frye is one that jumps to mind. It’s not specifically about dogs, but it’s been adapted by many who have lost pets. It reads:

Do not stand at my grave and weep,
I am not there. I do not sleep.
I am a thousand winds that blow.
I am the diamond glints on snow.
I am the sunlight on ripened grain.
I am the gentle autumn rain.
When you awaken in the morning’s hush,
I am the swift uplifting rush
Of quiet birds in circled flight.
I am the soft stars that shine at night.
Do not stand at my grave and cry;
I am not there. I did not die.

It’s a touching way of saying that while the dog may not be physically present, its spirit endures in the beauty all around us.

There’s also The Rainbow Bridge, author unknown, which is a poetic prose piece that promises a reunion with our pets after death in a serene place. Though not a poem in the strictest sense, its message is overwhelmingly comforting to pet lovers.

But if you want something more directly tailored to our canine friends, A Bridge Called Love by an unknown author offers a beautiful sentiment:

It takes us back to brighter years,
to happier sunlit days
and to precious moments
that will be with us always.
And these fond recollections
are treasured in the heart
to bring us always close to those
from whom we had to part.
There is a bridge of memories
from Earth to Heaven above...
It keeps our dear ones near us
It’s the bridge that we call love.

Sending any of these poems can be a tender gesture of understanding and shared sorrow. Grieving for a pet is hard, undeniably hard. Recognizing that with a poem is to acknowledge the depth of the bond your friend had to their beloved pup, and that can mean the world during tough times.

By the way, if your friend is a reader, and if it seems appropriate for their character, you might consider bringing them a copy of the incredibly touching novella, “The Art of Racing in the Rain” by Garth Stein. It’s told from a very thoughtful and introspective dog’s point of view and does a magnificent job of exploring the bond between humans and their canine companions.

And lastly, just being there for your friend is the most poetic gesture of all. Sometimes listening and a hug go a lot further than any words can.

~~~

Questions: Which is the first poem in the English literature?
Answers: The usually accepted answer to this Question is that the oldest recorded English poem is Caedmon’s Hymn, which dates from the sixth century. This is much earlier than works such as Beowulf, and about eight hundred years before Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales, which I see someone else has nominated. Caedmon was an illiterate farm worker, at the Abbey of Whitby, which was at that time run by a remarkable woman, the Abbess Hilda. Bede records the story for us, explaining that Caedmon worked with the abbey’s cows. In the evenings he would join the other lay brothers (i.e., people who worked in the Abbey but were not in Holy Orders) in eating and drinking together, but as soon as any singing began he would slip out to the cowshed, because he was very self-conscious about being ignorant and unable to sing, and would sleep there with his cows. He was clearly pretty miserable. One night when he had done this, he fell asleep as usual, and had a strange dream. A voice asked him, “Sing to me, Caedmon!” He refused, saying, “No, Lord, you know I cannot sing.” But the voice persisted, and finally he asked, “What shall I sing?” And the voice told him to sing of the story of Creation. So he did. The words just seemed to come to him as if from nowhere. And when he woke up in the morning, he could still remember the whole thing! He was so excited about it that he went and told one of the Brothers, who thought it was so amazing that he took Caedmon to the Abbess Hilda to sing it for her. And she had it written down, and we still have the words today. So that's it. Fifteen hundred years ago, the earliest recorded English poem. I should say that the extract below is only the opening - there is a fair amount more that follows. But this is how it starts, at any rate:Nu scylun hergan hefaenricaes uard  metudæs maecti end his modgidanc  uerc uuldurfadur sue he uundra gihuaes  eci dryctin or astelidæ  he aerist scop aelda barnum  heben til hrofe haleg scepen.  tha middungeard moncynnæs uard  eci dryctin æfter tiadæ  firum foldu frea allmectig Which, being interpreted, is to say: Now let me praise the keeper of Heaven's kingdom,  The might of the Creator, and his thought,  The work of the Father of glory, how each of wonders  The Eternal Lord established in the beginning.  He first created for the sons of men  Heaven as a roof, the holy Creator,  Then Middle-earth the keeper of mankind,  The Eternal Lord, afterwards made,  The earth for men, the Almighty Lord.

Questions: What's the best story you can write within 50 words?
Answers:
“Your bungalow is so big. You’re a very rich person, sir.” One guest complimented.
 
Raj looked at his late parents’ photograph hanging on the wall & confessed, “No. I’m not.”

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I love my sister Manya.

She’s my best friend! She’s older than me and doesn’t live at home anymore but that’s okay, because I see her a lot. She takes me to eat ice cream after school, and sometimes she takes me to soccer practice.

Manya is fun. She plays with me, and tickles me until I almost can’t breathe. For my birthday, she got me a big book with all the dinosaurs in it! I love everything about Manya.

Well, almost. I don’t like Manya’s cat. He’s a meanie. He scratches and scratches her until she has a million billion cuts all over her arm! But I’ve never seen her cat before. She told me that he leaves during the day and only comes back at night.

Why doesn’t she just lock her door? One time a bear came from the woods, and everybody locked their doors so the bear couldn’t come in. Maybe Manya could lock the door and the cat won’t come anymore.

I told her this and she didn’t say anything. Maybe she’s still thinking about it. She said not to tell Mommy and Daddy about the cat or the scratches on her arm because it’s a secret. I love secrets! When Manya tells me secrets I feel almost like a grown-up.

Manya tells me a lot of important secrets. I remember once she had a bruise on her neck. It was big and purple. Like my arm was when I fell out of the swing. When I asked her about it she cried. I don’t like it when Manya cries because it makes me very sad.

She told me she wouldn’t cry if I didn’t say anything to Mommy. I said I wouldn’t, but she cries anyway.

Manya cries a lot. I want to help her be happy, like she is in my photo album. I love looking at pictures of Manya. She used to be so little, and she smiled all the time. I don’t know why she stopped.

Yesterday, Mommy and Daddy dropped me off at Manya’s house for a sleepover! We watched Winnie the Pooh and she made me pizza rolls. Before we went to sleep, Manya cried again and she hugged me for a long time. But then she smiled, so I think she’s better now.

It’s morning now. I’m drawing Manya a pretty picture. She’s still sleeping next to me.

There’s an empty bottle on the table. I think it’s Manya’s grown-up candy that she eats sometimes. It’s small and round like M&Ms. But M&Ms are rainbow colored and Manya’s candy is plain white. I tried one when she wasn’t looking and it didn’t even taste good.

Silly Manya. Doesn’t she know that M&Ms taste better?

I don’t know why Manya ate the whole bottle. But I know that sometimes candy helps me when I’m sad. Maybe Manya was very sad and eating a lot of candy helped her feel better.

I’m all done with my picture. I drew me and Manya chasing her cat off a cliff. Take that, evil cat! Maybe my picture will make her so happy that she’ll never cry ever again!

Manya’s been sleeping for a long time. I tried waking her up, but she’s still sleeping. Maybe’s she’s very tired.

I hope she wakes up soon.

Questions: If Gaelic was the common language of Medieval Scotland, why did John Barbour compose his poem "The Bruce" in a dialect of English?
Answers:
Gaelic wasn’t the common language of Scotland by the 14th century, and hadn’t been for nearly the last 300 years.

At the beginning of the 1st millennium there were two languages spoken in Scotland, neither of which survive there today: Pictish north of the Forth-Clyde line and Brittonic south of it. (Brittonic is related to modern Welsh and Cornish. Pictish was most probably a Celtic language as well, but so little record of it survives that we can't even be sure of that.)

During the course of the first millennium three invader languages were imposed on Scotland as well: Gaelic from Ireland, English from northern Germany and Norse from Scandinavia.

Norse was primarily confined to the islands and the far northern tip of Caithness. English took root in the south-east, which was geographically a small area but contained a high proportion of Scotland's population.

As for Gaelic, it was initially the most successful of the new languages, starting in the south-west but replacing Pictish across most of the Highlands. This trend was linked to the merging of the Irish kingdom of Dál Riata with the various Pictish kingdoms.

In mediaeval Scotland and afterwards, it was generally held that the invading Gaels of Dál Riata had conquered the Picts to form the Kingdom of Alba, later known as Scotland. 'Scot', in those days, actually meant 'Irish', and 'Scotland' meant 'Land of the Irish'. Modern historians argue that it was more complicated than a simple conquest: for example, that the traditional 'first king of Scotland' Kenneth macAlpin was actually a Pict himself.

What is indisputable, however, is that the Pictish language became extinct and was replaced across most of Scotland north of the Forth-Clyde line by Gaelic. This extinction seems to have been quite rapid, occurring over the course of the 8th and 9th centuries, and very thorough. Gaelic, not Pictish, was the language of the Kings of the Scots.

Gaelic also eventually spread into south-west Scotland, the area where the Brittonic or Cumbric language had survived longest. This was actually due to a second Irish invasion in the 9th to 11th centuries, by hibernicised Vikings, the Gall-Ghàidheal people. They gave their name to Galloway, which was a semi-independent kingdom eventually absorbed by Scotland.

English, however, remained the common language of south-east Scotland, the area of Lothian and the Borders. This was part of the Angle kingdom of Bernicia and later Northumbria, but was isolated from the rest of English territory by the establishment of the Viking Kingdom of York in the 9th century.

The area of Lothian was thus vulnerable to a takeover by the Kingdom of Scotland. The year 973 is often taken to mark when this happened, since in that year Edgar, King of the English, formally acknowledged that Cináed ('Kenneth') mac Maíl Coluim, King of the Scots, was now the ruler of Lothian. Other historians say it happened later, in 1018. Written records from this period of history are sparse.

During the late 10th and 11th centuries, therefore, the area from Edinburgh to Berwick was an English-speaking region ruled by Gaelic-speaking kings. Unlike the Pictish and Cumbric-speakers to their north and west, however, the English of Lothian never adopted Gaelic as their language. Presumably they were too numerous to be absorbed or displaced. The fact that English was also spoken in the kingdom to the south is also likely have contributed to the survival of the language in Scotland.

However, by the middle of the 11th century Gaelic was already declining in prestige and influence.

In 1040 King Donnchad mac Crinain was killed in battle by the rebellious Mormaer of Moray, Mac Bethad mac Findláich, who seized his throne. (Shakespeare anglicised those names as 'Duncan' and 'Macbeth' in his play, though he fictionalised the circumstances of Duncan's death.) Donnchad's nine-year old son Máel Coluim (Malcolm) was probably taken to England for safety, and grew up speaking English at the court of Edward the Confessor.

As an adult Máel Coluim returned to Scotland in 1057 with English military assistance, defeated and killed Mac Bethad and his son, and became King of Scots the following year. A few years later Máel Coluim returned the favour when he allowed English exiles fleeing the Norman Conquest of England to reside in his kingdom. These exiles included Edgar Ætheling, who was regarded by many as the rightful heir by descent to the English throne.

In 1070 King Máel Coluim married the sister of Edgar Ætheling, Margaret. Since Edgar was childless, this meant that Máel Coluim's children with Margaret would be in line to the English throne. The King of Scots seems to have been very aware of this, since he did not give his sons traditional Gaelic names like his own, but thoroughly English names: Edward, Edmund, Ethelred and Edgar (followed by the more classical and Biblical Alexander and David).

Máel Coluim and his English wife Margaret, anachronistically wearing heraldic garments which would not actually be invented for another two centuries.

With an English-speaking king on the throne, married to an Englishwoman, and with many exiles from England having favoured positions at court, the Gaelic language was in eclipse among the elite. This trend seems to have been resented by the Scottish nobility: at least, when Máel Coluim died in 1093 they backed his Gaelic brother Domnall mac Donnchada to the throne instead of the king's anglicised sons.

However, Domnall did not hold the throne for long: in 1097 he was overthrown by Edgar with help from the King of England, William II. King Edgar ruled for ten years before being succeeded by his brother Alexander, who in turn was followed by their youngest brother David who became King of Scots in 1124.

Like his father, David had spent many of his younger years in England -- though by this time the elite language of England was Norman French, not English. Also like his father, David was closely related by marriage to the English monarchy, in this case because King Henry I of England married David's sister Margaret. (Which also meant that the Empress Matilda was David's niece.) David himself married an Englishwoman, Maud the Countess of Huntingdon, and by right of his wife was an English Earl before becoming King of Scots.

When David took the Scottish throne, by force, he did so at the head of an army of Anglo-Norman knights. He rewarded them later with lands and titles, resulting in the creation of a Scottish nobility with French roots. The most notable example is the Stewart or Stuart dynasty, founded by the Anglo-Norman nobleman Walter fitzAlan, who originally owned land in the Welsh Marches and whose father came to England from Brittany. Walter became the King of Scotland's steward, a title which became hereditary in his family and gave the dynasty its name.

David ruled Scotland for nearly three decades, and enacted sweeping reforms. He introduced a feudal system modelled on that of Norman England, with fiefs and oaths of vassalage. He divided his heartland where his power was strongest into counties controlled by sheriffs, again copying the English institution. He reformed the Church, reorganising its system of bishoprics and parishes, and setting up many new monasteries. The monks for these monasteries mostly came from England and France, and they provided a class of literate administrators to support David's reforms.

This meant that Scotland's new elite under King David included a very high proportion of Normans. The knights and barons who made up his army, and the monks and clerks who made up his administration, were most likely to speak French, secondly to speak English, and unlikely to speak Gaelic at all.

Finally, David reformed the economy as well. He minted Scotland's first coins, closely based on the English coinage. He also set up about 15 new towns, or burghs, which were given special privileges to allow them to become centres of trade and commerce. These burghs were mostly in the south-east, and up the east coast: they included Roxburgh and Berwick, the first two, followed by Aberdeen, Dundee, Lanark, Edinburgh, Dunfermline, Elgin, Forres, Linlithgow, Montrose, Peebles, Perth, Rutherglen, Stirling and Tain.

Not much is left of Roxburgh, King David’s first burgh, in modern times.

These were not all brand-new settlements as such, but David gave them royal charters and a new organisation. He also encouraged immigration of merchants and craftsmen from abroad -- these included many Flemings from Flanders, but also English, French and German inhabitants.

These new cities were mostly established in the English-speaking parts of Scotland, the area that was once part of the Kingdom of Northumbria. Immigrants to the burghs, if they were not already English-speaking, thus tended to learn English rather than Gaelic to get by.

The result of this century of change, from the accession of Máel Coluim Ceann Mòr (Malcolm III Canmore) in 1058 to the death of David I in 1153, saw the decline of Gaelic as Scotland's elite language. By the last years of David's reign the Scottish aristocracy mostly spoke Norman French, the urban middle class mostly spoke English, and only the peasants and the Highland clans still spoke Gaelic. Even they would often learn some English as a second language for use when they went into town to trade, or had to deal with the government and law.

Over the next two centuries, the primary development was that English spread its influence, Gaelic continued to retreat, and French gradually ceased to be the language of the nobility -- a change mirrored south of the border in England.

The Scottish wars of independence against England in the late 12th and early 13th centuries were eventually won by Robert de Brus, descendant of an Anglo-Norman baron who came to Scotland under King David I and brought up in the English-speaking region of Annandale, though he is believed to have also spoken Gaelic.

An important change was that by 1365 Edinburgh was being referred to as 'the capital of Scotland', replacing the more northerly city of Perth with that honour. That moved the centre of gravity of the royal court from the formerly Gaelic speaking realm of Alba to Lothian, which had been English-speaking for the last 750 years.

John Barbour wrote Brus in English in the year 1375, but he is noted as being the father of Scots literature. In other words, he was the first major Scottish literary figure remembered in history as writing in that language -- and the surprise is that he did not write in French or Latin, the main language of the Scottish elite for the last three centuries.

It seems that by the late 14th century English, the language of the merchants and urban classes, was rising in status and could now be spoken without embarrassment by poets and nobles. Early in the following century English replaced Latin as the official language of the government used for recording laws and the public accounts.

Sometime around the year 1500 an important change occurred. Until that point, the language now spoken by Scotland's elite was called English (or Inglis) while the term 'Scottish' (Scottis) referred to the language spoken in both the Highlands of Scotland and in Ireland — that is, Gaelic.

However, at about that point in time, the English-speaking Scots began using the term 'Irish' or 'Erse' to describe Gaelic, claiming the name Scottish, Scots or Scotis for their own language instead.

This can be seen as a rejection of the clan-based, Gaelic-speaking lifestyle of the Highlands as foreign, barbaric and unScottish. It was not until the 19th century that a romanticised picture of Highland life, with its bagpipes and tartans, was embraced as 'Scotland's heritage'.

Equally, it was an assertion of Scottish nationalism that the language they spoke was not 'English', but 'Scots'. Whether Scots is a language in its own right or a dialect of English is a question that most linguists will back away from nervously. Though as the saying goes, "a language is a dialect with an army and a navy".

Questions: What is the significance of J.R.R Tolkien's poem "All that is gold does not glitter"?
Answers:
This was from Bilbo’s poem about Aragorn, and Tolkien was paraphrasing Shakespeare a bit to get the meaning across.

The line from the poem first shows up in Gandalf’s letter to Frodo, which Barliman had forgotten to send, but hands it to him in Bree once he realizes that “Mr. Underhill” is Frodo. The letter tells Frodo to meet a man named Strider in Bree, who will guide them to Imladris. He includes the line along with a warning to be sure that it is the real Strider and not an imposter - he should be carrying a broken sword and his real name is Aragorn.

This positively identifies Strider as genuine, but Frodo states he had guessed the truth already, as an imposter would appear “fairer and fouler”. Aragorn, at this moment, is not looking his best. He is dirty and disheveled and Barliman thinks he is just some untrustworthy tramp, he “appears foul” But Frodo could tell from the kindness in his voice that he was no enemy, he “acts fair”. Frodo reasons that an imposter would go through great pains to appear fair, but would not act fair. This plays into the line in Gandalf letter, all that is gold does not glitter, Aragorn is the “gold” of great worth, but he does not “glitter” he is a dirty hobo.

We learn later that Aragorn cleans up nicely, but Boromir is initially dismissive of and disrespectful to Aragorn, something that angers Bilbo, who recites his poem angrily at Boromir, who does not see a king in Aragorn. There is more to it, of course, and the second line is just as important “not all who wander are lost” Aragorn wanders, but he is not lost, he is not in Gondor, but he is it’s rightful king.

Questions: What is the recent poem you wrote? What inspired you to do so?
Answers:
Last month, a lot of noise in my head birthed this poem. Hope, you comprehend my feelings through this poem:

I wonder

They travel to space

Many here

couldn't step out of four walls.

I wonder

They talk about freedom

Many here

couldn't make decisions for their own life.

I wonder

They lecture about morals and ethics

There are souls here

dying every day, following them.

I wonder

They make rules and feel proud

There are already many

Rotten and broken.

I wonder

They insist on maintaining silence

The noise in the head

has already created a menace.

I wonder

They go to war, claiming to bring peace

There are lives inside

Already shattered.

I wonder

They boast about gods and blessings

There are many here

Unblessed and deprived.

I wonder,

Yes, I wonder

At the contradictions

All around the world!

Thank you for reading.

Stay Calm!

Anshu.

Questions: What are some 5-line poems ending in "And so I did"?
Answers:
Though the battle was won,
Sprawling in the mud I was, dead
"I will give my life for freedom", I had said
A man of my words I was,
And so I did

Was driving at a very high speed
And they asked a fine for my deed
They were giving a receipt, I asked, "Sir, what's the need"
A 50 rupee note in his pocket, enough for our greed
Well, I had to reach the corruption protest in time, and so I did.


Poems if written by fictional characters:


"Darling! The dinner was great, I love you"
I love you too, I said
With lustful eyes towards me, she slid her gown and whispered
"Why don't you come closer and eat me instead?"
She didn't know the cannibal inside me, and so I did

- Hannibal Lecter

Waiting for the train we were and then it arrived
I darted for it to take me school
She shouted, "Hey! wait for me"
"Always", I said
And so I did.

- Severus Snape

Millions death on my hands lay
And I stand here in dismay
Had promised to save the world from others
But couldn't save it from myself
I always keep my promises, and so I did

- Ozymandias/Adrian Veidt

Questions: What are some tricks to memorizing poems?
Answers:
In 6th grade, I had an assignment.
In this assignment, we were given one week to memorize a poem by the author we were given.

I got Emily Dickinson.

Since I am me, I waited until the night before it was due to go “Oh shit! I have homework!” and frantically looked up a poem that had the minimum word count needed to pass.

I found Hope Is The Thing With Feathers.

I desperately tried to memorize the poem all night, but it was fruitless.
I was too tired and the words refused to stick in my brain.

The next morning, as I was being driven to school, I suddenly came up with an idea:
I would make up a tune to go with it!

Genius!

Throughout first period, I quietly hummed in the back of history class until I turned the poem into a song.

By the time I got to English class, I had it down solid. I could sing it in my sleep!

When my name was called, I proudly walked up to the podium in front of all my classmates and recited my poem.

No.

Wait.

That’s not how it happened.

Oh, right!

Actually, I belted my song out like I was Mariah fucking Carey.
Like, full vibrato and everything.
I’m pretty sure I was doing the ‘Christina Aguilera hands’ as I was singing, too.

I was feelin’ it.

It wasn’t until I finished that I noticed the laughter bubbling up from the corners of the room.

Shit.

Oops.

It’s been 15+ years and I can still recite that poem flawlessly.

Turn the poem into a song.

It really, really works.

Just don’t sing it in front of your entire class.

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I'm a big sister.

mommy and daddy say my brother is in her belly. mommies and daddies get babies when they love each other. I came from mommies belly. I might have baby belly too. people say they love me.

Mommies belly is big now. I don't fit on her lap. She sleeps all the time. I want to play with my brother. I talk mommy belly.

Grandma came to house. Mommy and daddy drove away. Mommy hurt. She cried a lot. She spilled red punch on the floor.

Grandma put my coat on. We go to the hospital. Mommy must need a cast. I can draw flower on it.

The hospital is loud. I hear beeps and people. It smells funny.

Mommy lays in bed. She is ghost white. The bed folds in half. I want to ride it. Daddy looks sad.

Daddy and grandma talk. They hug. I hug mommy.

Mommy kisses my head.

“I love my only baby" she says.

“I love you mommy.”

I talk to her belly “I love you brother.”

They start cry. The nurse is crying.

Daddy says my brother wants to stay in heaven.

It's ok. I will wait for him. He is just sleeping. I sleep too sometimes. I love him.

Questions: Can you write a poem about Quora?
Answers:
Yep. I call this work: “Quora C0ck Blocked.”

What’s this? An upvote!

On a post so old, I don't recall its crafting.

I read it. It’s garbage, I despair! *insert despairing interpretive dance pose*

Image source: Honestly, this could only be me.

Can it be? a superfluous comma!

Inside my prose, hides.

The artist within chagrined at such textual sin.

~

I am shamed, almost beyond reckoning.

But yonder lies the ‘edit’ function.

I exult. Can I polish this turd?

~

Alas, Quora tells me… “NO, 504!”

My revision is rejected and I weep.

For I am edit-c0ck-blocked.

~

Fin. *Hold final pose for applause*

Hey, If you wanted a GOOD poem, you should have put that request in the question.

**For those who only love me for my crayons, all stick-figgaz specific content is loaded here: Stickfiggaz -Crayons R'US

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I was thirsty. I tiptoed down the stairs, trying to make as little sound as possible. I grabbed the glass and noticed a light shining in the corner of my eye.

Somebody was awake. I was scared. I rubbed my eyes and walked towards the light. I saw daddy. He was with a woman. I looked closer. The woman had long, red hair and a blind-fold on.

It wasn't mommy though. Mommy has blonde hair.

I wondered why daddy was playing a blind-folded version of Twister with a stranger so late in the night. I didn't want to question him so I walked back into my room and fell asleep.

Mommy woke me up the next morning with a smile on her face. She was excited about her new product launching. I was still curious about last night.

“Good morning mommy. I saw daddy playing Twister with a woman last night. Why did they leave you out?”

Her smile turned into a frown. She looked at me with her sorrow eyes and stroked my hair.

“Don't worry son, mommy will take care of it. I always do, remember?”

Questions: What is a poem that has a hidden dark meaning?
Answers:
A Poison Tree by William Blake

I was angry with my friend:
I told my wrath, my wrath did end.
I was angry with my foe:
I told it not, my wrath did grow.

And I watered it in fears
Night and morning with my tears,
And I sunned it with smiles
And with soft deceitful wiles.

And it grew both day and night,
Till it bore an apple bright,
And my foe beheld it shine,
And he knew that it was mine,--

And into my garden stole
When the night had veiled the pole;
In the morning, glad, I see
My foe outstretched beneath the tree.

Blake’s poem is about the suppression of anger and how it leads to the cultivation of anger. The tree is the speaker’s anger, which he carefully tends. He waters it “Night and morning with my tears”. He “sunned it with smiles”, as his anger grows stronger. Until, the tree (his anger) produces “an apple bright”, which his foe then steals and eats, killing him. The speaker is happy to see “My foe outstretched beneath the tree.”. The foe has been ultimately destroyed by the speakers anger.

Blake wrote this poem in 1784, a time where it was important to keep your emotions bottled up inside, to show a happy face to society. Blake did not agree with this and in his poem he is telling us to let go of anger. We should not let it fester inside us and grow.

William Blake

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
They pulled my tiny cousin out of the ground today. His black hair was white. Like someone had dumped flour on his head. The rest of him was white too. Even his bright red t-shirt looked powdery.

He was under the building my auntie lives in. She doesn’t live in it anymore, I guess. It’s all in pieces. I don’t know where she’s gonna live now.

All the men in the village worked really hard to get my cousin out. They picked up blocks of stones and all kinds of things until they saw his arm under there. There was screams. The men were yelling so loud. It scared me, because I didn’t know why they were screaming.

It turned out good though. It was happy screaming. Because they’d found him. And he was still alive. But, he didn’t look so good. He was asleep. And all powdery. He didn’t talk or say anything.

The grown-ups put him in a truck and took him somewhere. To the doctor at the hospital, I think.

It’s not the first time a building has broken in our village. Dad says many people die when this happens. When the ‘bombs’ hit. Loud bangs. Screams. White powder and smoke everywhere.

I ask him why, and he always says it’s because of war. But why is there war? I ask. Because of politics, he says. I don’t understand. Why would politics want to hurt my little cousin? He is so sweet.

Dad says the people who do it are angry at their ‘enemies.’ Why don’t they just hurt their enemies instead? I ask.

Because war isn’t fair, my dad says.

Questions: Why are useless subjects like poetry taught in school?
Answers:
You’re learning how to learn.

Virtually everything you learn after grade six or so is just asking you to apply a concept that a textbook or your teacher just explained to you. Usually there’s an explanation, some examples, and then some sort of exercise to show that you were able to learn that new concept.

For poetry, you might read about what iambic pentameter is, read some examples, then be asked to produce your own poem in iambic pentameter.

Does anyone get paid to produce poems in iambic pentameter? Maybe like a dozen people in the world. You’re not going to be one of them. Neither am I.

But, do most people’s jobs involve a lot of learning new things? Youbetcha.

And that’s what you’re doing in school. You’re learning how to learn.

Questions: Are the Homeric epic poems still available to us in the original ancient Greek language that Homer himself used? How have the poems been preserved over time?
Answers:
Yes, they’re all written in a particular dialect of ancient Greek which is actually known as Homeric Greek. And that’s still the form in which we read them today, if we attempt to read them in the original.

I used to have a copy of the Iliad, bought in a Salonika bookshop, which had the original on one page and a modern Greek translation on the facing page, because modern Greek people have to learn classical Greek too. (Well, they don’t have to, I don’t think, but they do if they want to read classical Greek.)

One of the interesting things about the text of Homer is that, although the poems themselves are among the oldest in Greek literature, and indeed in European literature, so you’d think that they might have been altered or fiddled with over time and that the originals are lost beyond recall, in fact, the Greeks so revered Homer that they made copy after copy of his poems. So, even though he’s their classic just as he’s ours (if he’s ours), his text is one of the best established of all the Greek and Latin classics.

Compare the fate of Catullus, a Latin poet from around 750 years later than Homer, around half a century before the time of Christ.

Almost all of Catullus’ poems were lost for centuries, with the vast majority of them surviving in only one copy, which no longer even exists, and the only reason we know it existed is that other copies were made from it which contain notes from the scribes who made them, complaining that the manuscript they were copying from was obviously itself a poor copy of an earlier manuscript.

But Homer? You can walk into a bookshop and buy a copy of Homer in the original, and be reasonably sure that you’re reading the same poem that the Athenians were reading in 500 B.C.E.

I studied classical Greek in the hope that I would learn enough to be able to read Homer in the original. Unfortunately, his dialect is so different from the Attic Greek that I studied that I can’t. But it is possible to learn Homeric Greek, if you have the right textbook and a good teacher.

Answers:
Yessssss!!!!

There’s a club named LITERALLY SOCIETY (LITSO) which has very talented writers in it!

There are people who do stand ups, they are quite professional!

People write in college magazines and at other sources:

This part of the index shows some amazing pieces of art.

This is my writing in our college magazine - Dhanwantari!

Questions: As a teacher, what are your ways or your considerations in selecting the reading materials for your students, particularly in selecting poems?
Answers:
For novels, it’s fairly easy for me now. This is my twelfth year as a teacher, so I try to stick to novels I’ve already taught once before. That narrows it down to about 50 possibilities. I may add one new novel per year, but for the most part, I stick with what I know, because I already have the material, and there’s a good reason I taught it before… it’s relevant in some way to students in the age ranges I teach.

For poetry, I look for poems that are:

Catholic middle school-appropriate. So no graphic sex, violence, or drugs.
Relevant to middle school students. “Coming of age” or “growing independent” poetry is always a winner, since they’re in that phase of their lives.
Narrative. The students just seem to get more out of a poem that tells a story, rather than a poem that’s trying to capture an emotion. The big exception here is haiku.

About half of the poems I teach are actually just lyrics to popular songs. We read the lyrics, listen to the songs, then talk about them. It’s one of the most enjoyable things about being an English teacher. Country songs and 90s alternative hits, like from Counting Crows and the Gin Blossoms, work well for this.

Students also really enjoy reading “famous” poems or poems by poets they’ve heard of before: Poe, Shakespeare, etc…

The students’ literature anthology also has some pre-selected poems, complete with questions and discussion points, which makes my life easier.

The only poems I tend to avoid, because the students hate them and I don’t think they have much teaching value anyway, are free-verse poems by amateurs, like you may find on some poetry blogs online.

Questions: What is your favourite poem on Krishna?
Answers:
My favorite poems on Krishna, are the ones written by the great saint Meerabai.

One of the favorite poems describing the pain of separation which touched my heart:

As the lotus dies without water, as the night is blind without the moon, so is my heart without You, Beloved.I wander alone at night, driven by my longing for You. I hunger for You all the day, I thirst for You all the night.My grief is beyond words; my mind is beyond rest.

Come and end my grief, Beloved. Come and bring joy to my heart. You know my inmost secret; then look at me with eyes of love, Your slave for countless lives since the dawn of time.

A few lines from Meera’s poems shows us how to win over the Lord’s heart by treating him as our very own, and not as an authoritative god/dictator:

“Love in which there is laughter and sobbing, throbbing and clasping in tight embrace, that alone is liberation for me, I care for no other.”

” I will fasten the bells of His love to my feet and dance in front of my Beloved. Dancing and dancing I will please His eyes; My love is an ancient one. My love is the only truth.”

”I do not care about social norms nor do I keep my family's honor. I cannot forget, even for a moment, the beauty of my Lover. I am dyed in God's color. “

Finally Meera expresses the joy of having received Krishna’s vision in the below poem:

The Beloved has come to my house. After many an age of expectation, the abandoned one has found her Lover. The Beloved is compassionate and sent me a message.

My Beloved has come, every limb in my body throbs with joy. My love is for that Ocean of Love, the Beloved. His love has entrapped my eyes. Says Mira: He is joy abundant, I have enthroned Him on my brow.

I offer a thousand thanks to the astrologer who predicted my Beloved would come. My joy is overflowing, my soul has access to an incalculable storehouse of joy!

O my dear companion, now that I have seen the Lord, all my desires are fulfilled and my sufferings forgotten. My Master, the Ocean of Joy, Mira’s Lord, has entered her home.

|| Shri Krishnaya Namaha ||

Come and end my grief, Beloved. Come and bring joy to my heart. You know my inmost secret; then look at me with eyes of love, Your slave for countless lives since the dawn of time.

A few lines from Meera’s poems shows us how to win over the Lord’s heart by treating him as our very own, and not as an authoritative god/dictator:

“Love in which there is laughter and sobbing, throbbing and clasping in tight embrace, that alone is liberation for me, I care for no other.”

” I will fasten the bells of His love to my feet and dance in front of my Beloved. Dancing and dancing I will please His eyes; My love is an ancient one. My love is the only truth.”

”I do not care about social norms nor do I keep my family's honor. I cannot forget, even for a moment, the beauty of my Lover. I am dyed in God's color. “

Finally Meera expresses the joy of having received Krishna’s vision in the below poem:

The Beloved has come to my house. After many an age of expectation, the abandoned one has found her Lover. The Beloved is compassionate and sent me a message.

My Beloved has come, every limb in my body throbs with joy. My love is for that Ocean of Love, the Beloved. His love has entrapped my eyes. Says Mira: He is joy abundant, I have enthroned Him on my brow.

I offer a thousand thanks to the astrologer who predicted my Beloved would come. My joy is overflowing, my soul has access to an incalculable storehouse of joy!

O my dear companion, now that I have seen the Lord, all my desires are fulfilled and my sufferings forgotten. My Master, the Ocean of Joy, Mira’s Lord, has entered her home.

|| Shri Krishnaya Namaha ||", 'aiModelVersion': '1'}
