The most Heart-touching poem I ever wrote

Pain of silence

She remembered the exact time and date

The first time he kicked her in the stomach, straight

Startled she was, but never complained

She endured it all, without disdain

More violent kicks, and finally the pain

The physical trauma, the emotional drain.

Then came the pinch, hair-pull and unprovoked bite

Cursing loudly when she was out of sight

Questions: Can you write a poem on your dog?
Answers:
Please Leave Me Alone

11/5/2023 — God Guides What I Write, & Please Don’t Blame Gifted People for Your Problems nor Be Jealous of Their Gifts. Writing What Is in the Future…

Today, I buried my magnificent Black Chihuahua Cha Cha.
I loved her like music solfege — Do, Re, Mi, Fa, So, La.
Our love was bright & honest — but now a dark eclipse remains.
Now, there is an insidious, sinister viciousness that stains.

She kept up with me, walking quite rapidly & cheerfully.
Some days, it would appear as though I drained her energy.
But typically, Cha Cha would wolf down her doggy food,
And she would always run to me with a longing, obedient mood.

Many on social media were quite jealous of our love,
How our devotion & grace flew to Sistine, Everest heights —
Past the stained-glass windows of St. Paul with a peaceful dove,
Enveloped with the spirit of Mother Teresa’s theological rights.

Cha Cha barked at intruders who she knew were suspicious,
Doubtful of their intentions — likely hiding that which is egregious.
As writers, we must not stop writing what we notice in the periphery,
And as musicians, we must keep singing to awaken the scenery.

Cha Cha’s pink collar made it all the more salient that she was female,
Evident when I apparated through the door — how she would wail.
Her blackness reminded me of George Floyd & Breonna Taylor,
The lives they could have lived — but we as a society are a failure.

Questions: How can you analyze the poem "A Freedom Song" using combining intrinsic and feminism approach?
Answers:
Well…

What’s the point of telling you how I could do this… Let’s look at how YOU could do it…

To analyse the poem "A Freedom Song" using a delightful combination of intrinsic and feminist approaches, you must dance delicately on a grammatical tightrope. Imagine a linguistic circus act where the performer balances on the fine line between the inherent qualities of the poem and the empowering lens of feminism.

Now, delve into the poem's essence, its very soul. Scrutinize its structure, rhyme, and rhythm, dissecting each syllable with surgical precision. Seek to unravel the intricate tapestry of imagery, metaphors, and symbols woven by the poet. Unearth the underlying meaning and examine the linguistic devices that bring this freedom song to life.

And then, don your metaphorical feminist spectacles and gaze at the poem through their empowering lenses. Decipher the gender dynamics, challenge the patriarchal norms, and uncover the subversive messages lurking beneath the verses.

With these two approaches intertwined like a beautifully braided sentence, you can analyse "A Freedom Song" in all its glory. You honour the poem's intrinsic qualities while embracing the feminist lens, allowing them to dance together like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.

Now, venture forth and unravel the secrets of this remarkable poem!

How can you analyze the poem "A Freedom Song" using combining intrinsic and feminism approach?

Questions: Can you write a poem about Quora?
Answers:
The Quor.

Once upon a midnight dreary, I piddled, eyes weak and dreary.

Youtube shown before my eyes, top 10 lists becoming quite the bore—

With attention dropping, nearly stopping, a thought formed in my head.

Perhaps the internet went beyond, perhaps it offered something more,

A place to speak, a place to write, a place with knowledge to adore.

I thought back to a website by the name of Quor’

-

I stopped the vide’o robbing me of all intention,

Opening the site, for which creativity was the penchant.

Ideas bubbling, intuition doubling, I waited for the site to load.

As the page materialized, my concern began to soar.

For when it fully loaded, I saw to my abhor,

Quoth the server, 504.

Questions: What is the meaning of the Hindi poem posted by ADG PI of IAF after it attacked the Pakistani terror camp?
Answers:
The lines are from the famous “शक्ति और क्षमा” / “Shakti aur Kshama” / “Strength and Forgiveness” by the Indian poet रामधारी सिंह “दिनकर” / Ramdhari Singh “Dinkar”.

The crux of the poem is that in order to be benevolent and forgiving, one has to be powerful and feared first. Only then does the world take you seriously.

Only 2 of the 9 verses of the poem were posted.

'क्षमाशील हो रिपु-समक्ष
तुम हुए विनीत जितना ही,
दुष्ट कौरवों ने तुमको
कायर समझा उतना ही।

सच पूछो, तो शर में ही
बसती है दीप्ति विनय की,
सन्धि-वचन संपूज्य उसी का
जिसमें शक्ति विजय की।'

which roughly translates to

The more, in front of the enemy,
You were gentle and humane,
The more the evil Kauravas,
Pegged you as a craven.

Truth be told, it’s in the quiver,
Where lies the brilliance of humility.
And only his peace-offer is compelling,
Who are capable of victory.

The current situation between India and Pak is apt for this compilation. India has always championed peace and collaboration. And Pakistan has always mistaken it as India’s weakness. But India has to realize that you can only be magnanimous and forgiving if you are also perceived to be powerful and menacing.

There are three more paras that narrate the sequence of event in Ramayana where Lord Ram prayed to the Indian ocean separating India and Lanka asking for a way. He fasted and meditated for three days, but Lord Varuna (the Lord of the Seas), in all his haughtiness, did not respond.

On the fourth day, Lord Rama stood up, an embodiment of fury. He warns Varuna that he would dry up the entirety of the ocean if he did not pave way. Only then does Varuna realize the folly of his ways and takes on a human form, begging for mercy from the Lord.

तीन दिवस तक पंथ मांगते
रघुपति सिन्धु किनारे,
बैठे पढ़ते रहे छन्द
अनुनय के प्यारे-प्यारे।

उत्तर में जब एक नाद भी
उठा नहीं सागर से
उठी अधीर धधक पौरुष की
आग राम के शर से।

सिन्धु देह धर त्राहि-त्राहि
करता आ गिरा शरण में
चरण पूज दासता ग्रहण की
बँधा मूढ़ बन्धन में।

Finally, all of the poem’s core message is also contained in one single paragraph.

क्षमा शोभती उस भुजंग को
जिसके पास गरल हो
उसको क्या जो दंतहीन
विषरहित, विनीत, सरल हो।

which basically means that “the trait of forgiveness only suits that serpent that houses in it a deadly poison; no one really cares about the one who is fangless, gentle, and bereft of venom”.

There are three more paras that narrate the sequence of event in Ramayana where Lord Ram prayed to the Indian ocean separating India and Lanka asking for a way. He fasted and meditated for three days, but Lord Varuna (the Lord of the Seas), in all his haughtiness, did not respond.

On the fourth day, Lord Rama stood up, an embodiment of fury. He warns Varuna that he would dry up the entirety of the ocean if he did not pave way. Only then does Varuna realize the folly of his ways and takes on a human form, begging for mercy from the Lord.

तीन दिवस तक पंथ मांगते
रघुपति सिन्धु किनारे,
बैठे पढ़ते रहे छन्द
अनुनय के प्यारे-प्यारे।

उत्तर में जब एक नाद भी
उठा नहीं सागर से
उठी अधीर धधक पौरुष की
आग राम के शर से।

सिन्धु देह धर त्राहि-त्राहि
करता आ गिरा शरण में
चरण पूज दासता ग्रहण की
बँधा मूढ़ बन्धन में।

Finally, all of the poem’s core message is also contained in one single paragraph.

क्षमा शोभती उस भुजंग को
जिसके पास गरल हो
उसको क्या जो दंतहीन
विषरहित, विनीत, सरल हो।

which basically means that “the trait of forgiveness only suits that serpent that houses in it a deadly poison; no one really cares about the one who is fangless, gentle, and bereft of venom”.", 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: Could you write a paragraph that uses most innocent (childlike) words while describing the dark side of adults' world (betrayal, hypocrisy, etc.)?
Answers:
I can’t look away from the bloodied sidewalk, the mangled bicycle, and my little brother, crying loudly.

“If you had been watching him, he wouldn’t have fallen.”

“But, Mama, I couldn’t catch him. He was too far ahead of me!”

“Apologize to your brother for letting him get hurt!”

I mumbled a false apology and cried all the way back to the house. It wasn’t my fault. Mama was with him, too, but she was talking on her phone.

After dinner, I cleared the table and started to do the dishes. Mama left her chair pulled out and I tripped over it and dropped the plate I was holding.

“What did you do this time? Can’t you do something without causing a disaster? Clean this up, now!”

“But, Mama, you didn’t push in-”

“If you had a brain, you could have pushed it in yourself! This is all your fault”

Mama’s right. Mama was always right. It was my fault. I should have noticed the chair. Maybe if I wasn’t so dumb, bad things wouldn’t happen.

When everyone had gone to bed, I realized I needed to pee. I went to the bathroom and did what I needed to do, but when I flushed the toilet I heard footsteps. I braced myself.

“Don’t you think before you do anything? You just woke up your father and I! We have to be up early in the morning! Don’t use the bathroom at night! Go before. It’s like I raised an idiot.”

I should’ve just waited til morning to pee. Everything would be so much better if I wasn’t an idiot.

Questions: Can you write a poem about your lover?
Answers:
Casting shadows that are awkwardly placed.

There is no light that dances at her face.

She fumbles at night and kicks the bed edge.

Late morning riser she acts like she's dead.

Hogs up the bathroom, forgetting to flush.

I walk in behind her. Man it’s too much.

She leaves late for work. I'm always to blame.

She spent too much time, her hair wouldn't tame.

Forgetting her phone, in such a hurry.

Our house a mess, she left in a flurry.

Home after dinner, deciding I can't.

Asked her a question, her head took a slant.

“Everything ok, my sweet jelly bean?”

“The hell is your problem, what do you mean?”

“You seem so frazzled, I just had to ask.”

“Put it behind us. The past is the past.”

She turned on the stove and cooked us a meal.

It was burnt to a crisp, pasta and veal.

My composure I kept, so tightly wrapped.

Just couldn't tell her, thought it was crap.

Flipped on the telly and put on her show.

God it's so boring. She really not know?

She woke me for bed, the show now done.

I'm starting to think that she is the one?

She fell asleep fast, was left to my mind.

Is she my lover? This poem will find.

I don't hate when she's late, leaving lights on.

I don't hate when she sings, out of tune songs.

I don't hate when she yells — kicks, bites and screams.

Don't hate her at all, ’cause she's on my team.

She pulled my hair back, whenever I puked.

I know I'm in love. This isn't a fluke.

Puts on her makeup to act out a scene,

All in the name of keeping me clean.

She lifts me so high, with all of my flaws.

A lover like her, gives room for a pause.

Each of us is cracked, and broken in two.

But not for the world, would I trade Jessica Sue.

Happy four year anniversary, Jessica.

Lovingly,

Leon

Questions: What are the best poems written by Kabir Das?
Answers:
कबीर/Kabir ji was a poet without equals. The Indian poetic style of couplets (दोहे) are synonymous with him, as is the Bhakti (भक्ति) movement.

Almost every Indian would be familiar with some of his best couplets, e.g.

बुरा जो देखन मैं चला, बुरा न मिलिया कोय,
जो दिल खोजा आपना, मुझसे बुरा न कोय।

These lines are a critique of the inherent human nature to find faults in others all the while remaining blissfully unaware of their own prejudices and shortcomings.

Translation:

I ventured out to find evil, but to no avail.
But one search of my heart revealed evil nonpareil.

जिन खोजा तिन पाइया, गहरे पानी पैठ,
मैं बपुरा बूडन डरा, रहा किनारे बैठ।

Here is Kabir adjuring the reader to actually get up and get to work, to take risks, to go big.

Translation:

If you seek, you will find, but search the depths you should,
The timid are doomed to remain on the bank, muttering “I too could”.

अति का भला न बोलना, अति की भली न चूप,
अति का भला न बरसना, अति की भली न धूप।

Kabir warning of the evils of excess.

Translation:

An excess of words isn’t desirable, neither is prolonged mum.
Just like the extremes of a deluge and the sweltering sun.

However, my favorite, and sometime philosophical compass is his longform poem — मोको कहां ढूँढे रे बन्दे !

मोको कहां ढूँढे रे बन्दे
मैं तो तेरे पास में
ना तीरथ मे ना मूरत में
ना एकान्त निवास में
ना मंदिर में ना मस्जिद में
ना काबे कैलास में
मैं तो तेरे पास में बन्दे
मैं तो तेरे पास में

ना मैं जप में ना मैं तप में
ना मैं बरत उपास में
ना मैं किरिया करम में रहता
नहिं जोग सन्यास में
नहिं प्राण में नहिं पिंड में
ना ब्रह्याण्ड आकाश में
ना मैं प्रकुति प्रवार गुफा में
नहिं स्वांसों की स्वांस में
खोजि होए तुरत मिल जाउं
इक पल की तालास में
कहत कबीर सुनो भई साधो
मैं तो हूं विश्वास में

Translation:

Why do you search for me elsewhere, my son!
If you seek me, look inside.
Neither with pilgrimages, nor with idols,
Nor with solitude do I abide.
I am not fond of temples or mosques,
In Kaaba or Kailasa, I do not reside.
I have always been with you, my friend.
If you seek me, look inside.

Prayers, invocations, fasts, or rituals,
Everything you can lay aside.
Not over the body, or the soul,
Not over the earth or sky do I preside.
I can’t be found in caves or whirlpools,
Or in the life force allied.
If you sincerely pursue me,
You will find me in a single stride.
Kabir says, “heed my words!”
Just with faith am I gratified.

अति का भला न बरसना, अति की भली न धूप।

Kabir warning of the evils of excess.

Translation:

An excess of words isn’t desirable, neither is prolonged mum.
Just like the extremes of a deluge and the sweltering sun.

However, my favorite, and sometime philosophical compass is his longform poem — मोको कहां ढूँढे रे बन्दे !

मोको कहां ढूँढे रे बन्दे
मैं तो तेरे पास में
ना तीरथ मे ना मूरत में
ना एकान्त निवास में
ना मंदिर में ना मस्जिद में
ना काबे कैलास में
मैं तो तेरे पास में बन्दे
मैं तो तेरे पास में

ना मैं जप में ना मैं तप में
ना मैं बरत उपास में
ना मैं किरिया करम में रहता
नहिं जोग सन्यास में
नहिं प्राण में नहिं पिंड में
ना ब्रह्याण्ड आकाश में
ना मैं प्रकुति प्रवार गुफा में
नहिं स्वांसों की स्वांस में
खोजि होए तुरत मिल जाउं
इक पल की तालास में
कहत कबीर सुनो भई साधो
मैं तो हूं विश्वास में

Translation:

Why do you search for me elsewhere, my son!
If you seek me, look inside.
Neither with pilgrimages, nor with idols,
Nor with solitude do I abide.
I am not fond of temples or mosques,
In Kaaba or Kailasa, I do not reside.
I have always been with you, my friend.
If you seek me, look inside.

Prayers, invocations, fasts, or rituals,
Everything you can lay aside.
Not over the body, or the soul,
Not over the earth or sky do I preside.
I can’t be found in caves or whirlpools,
Or in the life force allied.
If you sincerely pursue me,
You will find me in a single stride.
Kabir says, “heed my words!”
Just with faith am I gratified.', 'aiModelVersion': '1'}

Questions: What are the best poems written by you after your breakup?
Answers:
I guess a lot of you must be familiar with the page The Scribbled Stories on Facebook. Well the following poem was written in response to one of their micro tales. This was written close to after a month after my breakup

Picture Courtesy: The Scribbled Stories

And here is my poem in response to their tale

I bowed down to your anger,
not once, not twice, but every-time
it showed up in an otherwise calm being.
I bowed down to your anger,
cause after the tumultuous raging storm,
that calm self would return.
I bowed down to your anger,
cause when you are finally out of its clutches,
you would place my head on your lap
and run your fingers through my hair.
I bowed down to you anger,
so that I could close my eyes,
in utter bliss as your fingers
drew curls out of my otherwise straight hair.

I bowed down to your anger,
just like everytime,
however the anger wasn’t there to be found.
The calm self was still calm,
but now emotionless.
I was shoved down naked to the steel floor,
trampled on over and over again.
I still bowed down to your anger,
hoping this too shall pass.
I was waiting for you to pull me
to your bosom and soak in all my pain.

I was left waiting on the icy cold floor.

Djokester

I had posted this as a comment on the post and it was soon the most liked comment.

The Scribbled Stories

Peace!

Questions: I want to use a poem in my book but can't track down the author. The poem is printed in various places on the internet. Can I use it in my book without her permission?
Answers:
Laura Lee Rose is not correct. You cannot use a work that is under copyright without the author’s written permission. The law does not recognize “I couldn’t find the person” or “I don’t know who it is” as an excuse.

Including a note that you don’t own the work and/or don’t know who owns it means zero in copyright law. It will keep from getting accused of plagiarism, but that is a completely different thing.
